awd_titl_txt: REU Site: MedIX: Medical Informatics Experiences in Undergraduate Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The main objectives of the Medical Informatics (MedIX) Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site program are to engage undergraduate students in challenging research projects, encourage them to pursue graduate education, and expose students to interdisciplinary research, especially at the border of information technology and medicine. The MedIX REU Site runs for three summers, with ten student participants doing research ten weeks each summer under the supervision of five mentors dedicated to undergraduate research. The REU Site is hosted by two interdisciplinary laboratories: the Medical Informatics Laboratory at DePaul University and the Imaging Research Institute at the University of Chicago. The research environment offers the students the opportunity to interact with computer scientists, medical physicists, and medical doctors.

All of the projects are inspired by state-of-the-art research questions in imaging informatics. Students work as part of faculty-undergraduate teams on new problems ranging from traditional image processing (e.g., computer-aided diagnosis, breast density assessment, cancer detection) to structured reporting and natural language processing of radiology reports, to workflow and process re-engineering to the application of data mining and ontology-based means for image annotation and markup (e.g., lung nodule detection and interpretation). Ultimately, this REU site will help support students interested in imaging informatics, broaden participation in computer science. In addition, each project has the long-term potential to increase the quality of healthcare available to people everywhere. More information on the program can be found at the MedIX REU Site web site (http://facweb.cs.depaul.edu/research/vc/medix).
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Demographics and Student Prior Experience  

Demographics: The NSF REU Program in Medical Informatics 2017-2019 provided research experiences to 30 students selected from 298 applicants (10% acceptance rate): 16 students (53%) were women, 4 were African American or Hispanic (13%), 4 were first-generation college students (13/%), and 30 (100%) were from outside the hosting institutions.  These percentages are generally consistent across all fifteen years of the program, with an increase in the number of students from outside institutions (100%) and female students (60%) in the last year of the REU MedIX program.  Given the interdisciplinary nature of the program, students’ background covered a large number of majors including electrical engineering, biomedical science and engineering, mathematics, and neuroscience.

Student Prior Experience: The MedIX program was the first significant research experience for most of the students.  Fewer than half reported that they had (other than for course work) previously given a visual (poster) research presentation (42%) or an oral research presentation (39%) or authored or co-authored a publication in an academic journal (10%).  When asked how much time they spent in a research environment, 10% reported experience in an industrial research environment, and 55% reported experience in an academic research environment.  This statistics fits very well with one of the goals of the MedIX program: to provide students with limited research resources the opportunity to publish and present their work at a conference.

Program Effects on Student Attitudes and Self-efficacy

Program Effects: An 8-item self-efficacy and attitude scale (1 - strongly disagree to 5 - strongly agree) survey was administered at both the beginning and end of the program.  Two of the items measured self-efficacy beliefs, and two measured positive attitudes about research.  For "I am confident in my ability to discuss research findings...” the mean rating increased from 3.2 to 3.5, and the percentage of students indicating agreement increased from 39% to 70%.  For "I am confident in my ability to evaluate research findings...” the mean rating increased from 3.0 to 3.4, with an increase in agreement from 30% to 74%.  Thus, the student responses indicate that the MedIX REU greatly increased students' confidence in their abilities to engage in scientific research.  With regard to the post-survey question: "Because of my participation in this program, I am more likely to attend graduate school", 72% indicated they agreed or strongly agreed, with a mean agreement rating of 3.8. 

Highlights on Students’ Accomplishments

Publications: The REU students’ work from 2017 to 2019 resulted in 17 conference papers, extended abstracts, and presentations, and 3 journal papers; 26 out of the 30 student participants were co-authors of these papers.  All REU-related publications can be found at the MedIX site. 

NSF Graduate Research Fellowships: Two female students received the NSF fellowships in support to their PhD studies; one is in the first year of the PhD program at Northwestern University and another one in the second year of the PhD Program at Harvard University.

Contribution within Medical Informatics Discipline: MedIX students have made a number of contributions within the field of medical informatics and these contributions can be seen from looking at the list of publications.  A focus, then, on the summer of 2019 would include contributions such as segmentation of drusen in optical coherence tomography (OCT) images, the quantification of uncertainty in medical text,  and an in-depth look at the automatic evaluation of brain grey-white matter differentiation.

Contributions to Other Disciplines:  The work done on analyzing mental health discussions on Reddit could be used to analyze other conversations outside mental health.  All of the techniques and analysis were developed independently of the nature of the conversation.  Likewise, the use of 3D Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) is already increasing, and while most 3D imaging is done in medicine, 3D GANs could be applied in other areas as well.

The NSF CISE REU Site PIs meeting, February 22-23, 2021

DePaul University, the Illinois Institute of Technology and the University of Chicago hosted the NSF CISE REU Site PIs meeting virtually.  The goal of this meeting was to bring together the PIs from all the CISE programs and engage in conversation to improve the quality of all REU programs. There were 165 registered participants, with 60 registrations from new sites (30 were PIs, and 14 were co-PIs). The NSF CISE REU PIs meeting 2021 included four panels with breakout sessions such as best practices for running virtual REU sites, reporting, and writing highly competitive renewals.

In addition, there were networking opportunities, a chance for PIs to meet with their Program Officer, and a meeting between S-STEM PIs and REU PIs to encourage collaboration on programs and proposals.  Furthermore, attendees were encouraged to submit posters and videos from their site as exemplars for all REU PIs. All the material from the PI’s meeting is available online at http://reupi2021.cs.iit.edu/.

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2021
Modified by: Daniela Raicu
